strong.span: Latest Updates from Farmington Public Schools

div.p: Given recent updates and information from Governor Lamont and DPH, along with the emerging active spread of the COVID-19 in areas of Connecticut, will be closed through May 20, 2020.

li.strong: Grab and Go Breakfast and Lunch will be available to all families in need at Farmington High School on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays from 11:00 am -1:00 pm.
Farmington Continuing Education has online complimentary and fee-based
course offerings for youth and adults.
Visit our website (www.fpsct.org/fce) for a complete list of c
ourse offerings as NEW offerings are being added daily!

ul.li: Please see the updated guidance from Farmington Valley Health District and the CDC regarding face coverings.

The intention of this closure is to allow for social distance to hopefully slow the spread of the virus. Governor Lamont has ordered that all social and recreational gatherings larger than 5 persons other than essential school or municipal functions be cancelled. Please be vigilant in avoiding gatherings

li.a: Creative things to do with your child
Does my student need a Chromebook?

div.p: Our goal is to have students connected to us, connected to learning and connected to one another. To that end, we hope this Connected Learning plan will offer:
Ongoing and Meaningful Instruction: Allow students to continue their learning at home with meaningful instruction and feedback from their teacher(s) through a digital platform.

Social Connection: Create a sense of continuity and help students maintain connections with school during an extended school closure. As much as possible, we will help students manage any possible worries or fears.
Equitable Education and Supports: Provide appropriate resources and personalized supports so that all students can continue to progress in their skills and knowledge.

strong.span: Check out the Connected Learning site at:

p.strong: Learning never ends! Use the time you have in the next two weeks to explore some new, interesting topics and/or to review some past material. We have posted links at
with many suggested resources and ideas your teachers have shared for your continued learning.

h2.a: Creative things to do with your child

ol.li: Build a routine. Create a calendar or daily schedule for each day. Give each day a learning activity or even a small daily “homework” assignment that you might give your child. You can build in games or rewards around finishing those assignments. Kids operate well around schedules, and a routine schedule can help a child stay focused and centered on the regularity of a daily routine. This will help balance both small pockets of working time with playing time.

Engage your child with crafts. Time flies when you’re having fun, and crafting can be lots of fun for your child (and for you!). You can make candles, jewelry, holiday baskets, costumes, drawings, and lots more! Ask your child what he/she would be interested in creating. Find small household material to make interesting creations.

Lots of time for reading! Just because you are home does not mean that the books go away! This is the best time to read books for fun. So whether it’s your child’s favorite comic, story, or holiday tale, be sure to visit your local library online collection or check out the books available on the school library websites through RAZ-Kids or EPIC.

Have fun cooking together! Whether it’s a favorite cookie recipe or side dishes for dinner, cooking together can be an engaging way not only to bond but also to learn! Reading recipes is a great way to practice real-life math skills by measuring cups and spoonfuls of different ingredients. Cooking also involves following directions, which is a good skill for students to continue to learn!

Have a game night. This can be a fun way to bond with loved ones while playing interactive games that will continue to teach your child things such as cooperating, working in a team, strategizing, and having fun!

div.p: Internet Essentials Free for New Customers: Individuals or families looking to sign up for Internet Essentials should call 1-855-846-8376 or visit https://www.internetessentials.com/covid19. Additionally, for all new and existing Internet Essentials customers, the speed of the program’s Internet service was increased to 25 Mbps downstream and 3 Mbps upstream. That increase will go into effect for no additional fee and it will become the new base speed for the program going forward.

p.br: Xfinity WiFi Free For Everyone: Both customers and non-customers can access outdoor and small business-based Xfinity Wi-Fi hotspots for free for the next 60 days. Xfinity customers can download the Xfinity WiFi app and find the nearest hotspot on the map view. Non-customers can find their nearest hotspot by visiting https://wifi.xfinity.com and entering their zip code.

div.p: Grab and Go Breakfast and Lunch will be available to all families in need at Farmington High School on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays from 11:00 am -1:00 pm. Families are asked to report to the cafeteria doors in the FHS circle. Please utilize the student parking lot for parking.
If families have no transportation or complications to obtain grab-and-go, please reach out to Farmington Dial-a-Ride at 860-793-3444.

h2.a: Does my student need a Chromebook?

div.p: All technology-based learning activities are designed to use Google Chrome and associated extensions. Students can use any device with the Chrome browser. We are doing the best to limit the amount of necessary screen-time.
Any device that is internet enabled and/or can run Google Chrome browser can be used. If devices or connectivity are an issue, please reach out to your student's principal for assistance.

p.strong: If you have questions about COVID-19, please call 211. If you have symptoms, please contact your health provider.

div.p: If your child or any family members have a fever or symptoms of COVID-19: Immediately call your physician for guidance. Please see the guidance related to supporting your child physically and emotionally, especially during this school closure period.

p.strong: Coronavirus (COVID-19), causes respiratory illness in people and can be spread from person to person. Symptoms include fever, cough, and shortness of breath. Since its initial outbreak, thousands of cases have been reported in China with additional cases confirmed in other countries, including the U.S.

div.p: We are including updated information about social distancing from the FVHD here.

A Message from Farmington Valley Health District (FVHD):
Due to the rapid escalation of COVID-19 cases across the country, in our state and our District and the proportionately small number of individuals that are actually being tested in CT, we need to move to a model that assumes that anyone suffering fever, cough or difficulty breathing has COVID-19.
Please study this simple chart to help you determine what actions you and your family need to take to protect yourselves and slow the spread of this virus in our communities.
Remember – We are in this together!
Please see the information posted on our Connected Learning site:

strong.em: Please keep us informed when you, your child or a family member in your household:

ul.li: Is returning from a trip from areas highlighted on this CDC website, https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel. Again, this is a best practice to try to limit the spread of COVID-19. This site is updated in real time, so please periodically review this website.
All school-sponsored out-of-state and international travel at FHS and throughout the district cancelled.

Similarly, the CIAC has cancelled all sports related tournaments at this time. We will continue to stay in contact with the CIAC to provide updates to our school district community. Again, this decision is extremely challenging for our athletes, coaches and school district. Our athletes and coaches have worked tirelessly to reach this level of competition. Please know we are working in collaboration with our coaching staff to support our student athletes as we await next steps from the CIAC.
We will no longer have field trips outside of the school district until further notice. Again, we want to avoid large gatherings of individuals, especially outside of our schools.
We are suspending all work related travel for employees until further notice related to conferences and/or visits to other schools

div.p: As you might imagine, planning for and responding to a potential health emergency like COVID-19 requires thoughtful and measured decisions to be made in many different areas. I want to assure you that we are working closely on each of these areas with our education, health and wellness, and community partners, including the FVHD, the DPH, the CSDE, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), local physicians including our Medical Director (Barbara Ziogas, M.D.), our Director of Health Services (Sue Beardsley, R.N.), our Emergency Management Director (FPD Chief Paul Melanson), UConn Medical Center, the Town of Farmington, and other individuals and agencies. We also are in regular communication with neighboring school districts to share resources and best practices. Please know that we must all work together to prevent the spread of this illness. The more each individual follows the preventative recommendations, the more we will minimize the impact of this illness.
